Posts.Title: Radiation January 2019 egregious egregious

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2019 02:33PM - edited Jan 15, 2019 03:15PM by PurpleCat Just popping in from the December thread to see how those who carried over into January are doing. DeeDee and Dani, you are so close to being done! Time to think about celebrating! I've been done for just two weeks. I had 15 regular sessions plus the five boosts, so it's really been three weeks since I had a whole-breast zap, and that skin looks really good. Not like the un-radiated side, but definitely heading toward normal. The boosted area is a bit more pink still but also improving quickly. The nipple is looking a lot better too and really isn't painful any more. Today I don't think the breast is any more painful then it's always been at certain times of my cycle. So, those of you still going through it, it really does get better! I've been pretty sleepy in the afternoon, but that might not be related to radiation. I am set to take my first tamoxifen pill tonight, and I am a little nervous about that, but keep telling myself what it's for and that if it's unbearable I'll just talk to my doctors about possible alternatives. Hang in there, everyone! One day closer!

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2019 12:13AM - edited Feb 16, 2019 12:15AM by PurpleCat Hi Sagelady, I'm so sorry things turned out this way, but in my experience, the part you just got through was the absolute worst phase, emotionally, of my entire journey. After my sentinel node biopsy, after getting good results but still experiencing a lot of pain, I told someone that I would far rather be experiencing that physical pain than waiting for that initial biopsy report. Waiting for test results is just torture, and there's nothing that makes it better. But if you can get through that, which you just did, you can get through the rest. As to whether IDC would have been seen on the biopsy, I was told that 10-15% of the time the final pathology report from DCIS surgery (my initial diagnosis, although it's not in my signature) reveals IDC too. Unfortunately, I was in that small percentage, which was pretty upsetting because it meant a second surgery to get lymph nodes, then additional waiting to find out if they were clear. They also did oncotype testing on the IDC, so I had to wait for that score too. But the nodes were clear, and the score was low, and in the end I had the exact same treatment they had outlined for me after the DCIS biopsy: lumpectomy, radiation, and tamoxifen. So the only thing that really changed was that after a month of thinking I had Stage 0, which never gets chemo, I spent about two weeks bracing myself for the possibility that I would need chemo after all. By then I was so sick of the waiting game I would have happily accepted chemo if it meant just getting ON with treatment! Hang in there, Pegasus. I'm praying it's just more of the same-old same-old for you!

Posts.Title: Fibroadenoma deciding to grow?!?! sparrowhawk sparrowhawk

Posts.Content: PurpleCat wrote: For the third time in my life I am relieved to have benign results from a breast biopsy. I am also feeling a little hopeless. ¬†Benign is great, but my goodness, how many more of these things am I going to experience? ¬†Will I ever learn not to panic, losing sleep and appetite for days until the results are in? ¬†I can't take for granted that the next one will be benign. I found my first lump at 28. ¬†The doctor said it was almost certainly benign, and sent me for US since I was too young for a mammogram. ¬†Open biopsy confirmed a fibroadenoma. ¬†Seven years later, I found a second lump, and again the doctor thought it felt benign. ¬†This time I was old enough for a mammogram, but the lump didn't show up due to my dense tissue. ¬†Ultrasound and needle biopsy confirmed it was another fibro, and I opted to just let it be. ¬†It has since disappeared, or become too small to feel. Last week I felt my third lump. ¬†I was almost calm about it at first, because it felt so much like the first two lumps: ¬†firm, slippery, maybe about 1 cm. ¬†Anxiety took over within minutes, but what got me through the next several days until my appointment was the thought "This is probably just another fibroadenoma. ¬†If there's one thing I know by now, it's what a fibroadenoma feels like, and this feels just like the other two did." ¬†The nurse who did my clinical exam said it felt like a fibroadenoma to her, which was reassuring. ¬†Next came the mammogram. ¬†Again, no findings, due to dense tissue, so off to the ultrasound room. Now, here's where it gets interesting. ¬†The radiologist plunked that sensor down and announced "You have a cyst." ¬†Cyst??? ¬†I asked how big it was: ¬†one inch. ¬†ONE INCH??? ¬†I was flabbergasted, but relieved. ¬†Cysts can be drained. ¬†But the thing I had been feeling felt way more like a 1 cm fibro than a 1 inch cyst. ¬† While I was still wrapping my head around this new information, she moved the sensor a bit and said "And over here is a solid mass, but it's probably too small to feel. ¬†Looks like a fibroadenoma." ¬†I asked how big it was: ¬†8 mm. ¬†Okay, so I have TWO lumps? ¬†I asked which one I had been feeling, and she said it had been the cyst. ¬† So now I'm completely gobsmacked because the one thing I was sure of was that I knew what a 1 cm fibroadenoma felt like. ¬†Now I'm learning that I do have a solid mass in my breast, but I probably wasn't able to feel it. ¬†And if I wasn't able to feel it, that means I DON'T know if it was smooth, slippery, and moveable, which means that now it definitely could be cancer. ¬†All my confidence about it being a benign fibroadenoma melted away, and the total fear I'd been fighting off for days just took over, even though the tech and the radiologist were both referring to it as a fibroadenoma. So I asked the radiologist, "What do I do about this? ¬†You're telling me I have a solid mass, but I wasn't able to feel it, it didn't show up on mammogram because of dense tissue, and if I hadn't found this cyst right next to it, I never would have known it was there? ¬†How do I know I don't have anything else going on in there?" ¬†Honestly, I was so wound up inside (although outwardly calm) that I don't really even remember what he said, but he mentioned MRI as a possibility if there's a family history of BC (there isn't). ¬†He also said something about how looking around more could lead to a lot of unnecessary biopsies, which gave me the impression that my breasts are probably just full of little bits of junk just slowly growing until they're actually big enough to find, and the best I can do is just pray that none of them are malignant. ¬†Ugh. Is there anyone who can relate? ¬†Honestly, I am so grateful not to have cancer, but right now I don't even feel confident about that. ¬†If mammograms can't see confirmed lumps in my dense tissue, how do I really know I don't have cancer? ¬† Dx 10/2018, IDC, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 10/4/2018 Lumpectomy Surgery 10/18/2018 Lymph node removal: Sentinel Hormonal Therapy Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Radiation Therapy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Benign again, but now what? PurpleCat PurpleCat

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2018 12:40PM PurpleCat wrote: I'd like to know too. I had a lumpectomy 4 weeks ago, then SNB 2 weeks ago, and have been really surprised at the pain. The nerves are going bonkers for several inches in all directions from the SNB site, and there are too many unpleasant sensations to describe, even itching. I know it's normal to feel pain, I just didn't expect it to be so troublesome 2 weeks later, and would tolerate it better if had some clue when it might improve, or at least when it's reasonable to ask for physical therapy, gabapantin, etc. When I think that it might not feel better before I add radiation side effects to to the game, I just want to cry.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 08:14PM PurpleCat wrote: This is a great idea! ¬†When I found my first lump, I was scared to death because I hadn't ever known anyone who had a benign lump, only cancer. ¬†Then I started quietly telling people what was going on, and it turned out I knew a LOT of people who'd had benign lumps; they just hadn't ever talked about them before. ¬†It was so reassuring to find out how common they are, even though only benign biopsy results could set my mind at ease, and I'll probably be just as scared as ever next time this happens. ¬†¬† I've found 3 lumps. ¬†The first two turned out to be fibroadenomas; the third was a fibroadenomatoid hiding behind a cyst. ¬†All felt smooth and slippery, but scared the dickens out of me at the time because I'm an anxious person and there just aren't any guarantees, ever. In addition, a good friend of mine had had several scares, all of which have turned out fine so far. ¬†She's lost track of how many, but one resulted in a steroscopic biopsy that ended up being fibrocystic junk. ¬†The most recent one evidently looked quite alarming on her mammogram, but turned out to be just a cluster of small cysts. ¬† May this thread be a blessing to many, and may it overflow with benign results!

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 08:13PM PurpleCat wrote: The waiting is agony, isn't it? ¬†My mammogram is tomorrow also, and I fully expect an ultrasound as well. ¬†If you're like me, your mind is running through every possible outcome right now. ¬†Both of my previous lumps were mobile, and I was told that was a good sign, and it was; they were both benign. ¬†That's not a diagnosis, but maybe it's something to hang on to to get you through the night. ¬†I'm also reminding myself of how very many people I know who have survived cancer, and although the treatments were crummy, they got through them and are doing just fine now. ¬† I don't have any idea if you believe in prayer or not, but I do, and sometimes when I can't sleep at night (as will probably be the case tonight) I start praying for people, so I will be praying for you tonight as well. ¬†
Posts.Title: Diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound TOMORROW IndyAnony IndyAnony

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 09:51AM PurpleCat wrote: You can drive yourself crazy trying to interpret your own ultrasound results. Believe me, I've been there. ¬†Had myself in a complete and total panic the other night because from one angle my lump looked to me as you'd described: nice smooth eggplant shape. ¬†Then from a different angle I saw a couple of definite bumps. ¬†Mind you, the radiologist and the technician were both referring to it as a fibroadenoma, but that still wasn't good enough for me. ¬†Oh no, I had to go googling that evening for pictures of fibros on ultrasound. ¬†One picture came up with a jaggedy looking lump that looked, to my completely untrained eyes, a lot like what I had seen in my own picture. ¬†I found this reassuring until I actually read the information on the caption, which turned out to be part of a presentation for medical students and essentially said "THIS IS NOT A FIBROADENOMA: DO NOT EVER THINK IT MIGHT BE!!!" ¬†Oh my word, I thought I was going to die right then. ¬†Then the next day I had biopsy results back already: ¬†benign. ¬†Just like the radiology people had predicted. Moral of story: ¬†let the experts do their job. ¬†They really do know what they're doing; they see thousands of these things each year, and the ones I had the other day were confident enough to pronounce what they were seeing right on the spot, even before the biopsy. ¬†¬† (But - FWIW, what you described sounds like every cyst or fibro I've ever had. ¬†Hope that helps! ¬†)

Posts.Title: How Fatigued were you during rads treatment? kec1972 Carol2018

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2019 04:36AM PurpleCat wrote: Your dx sounds very similar to mine. I had my lumpectomy and SNB as separate procedures 2 weeks apart, both on Thursdays, and was back to work by Monday both times, although my job is pretty sedentary. I underestimated how sore and stiff I was going to be after the SNB, which took just 3 nodes. I used the arm as little as possible and mostly held it close to my body, so much that coworkers commented on it. There was noticeable improvement week by week, and by the end of the 4th week I felt not quite back to pre-surgery comfort but close enough that I could use the arm normally again. It would have been difficult to take care of young children, but kids old enough to fetch and carry things and help with some household tasks would have been amazing.
Posts.Title: Recovery Time for Lumpectomy with sentinel node biopsy? kec1972 kec1972

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2012 06:10PM - edited Nov 2, 2012 06:14PM by PurpleCat Hooray for benign results! I had my first fibroadenoma removed in open biopsy. Doctors told me it was fine to leave it be, but I wanted it out for peace of mind, and they obliged. ¬†It left a 2 inch scar and evidently enough scar tissue to perplex radiologists. When I found a second one a few years later, my initial reaction again was "just get this thing out of me" but ultimately decided that one 2-inch scar was enough and opted to leave it alone. However, for reasons I can't fully explain, finding this second lump had been really frightening, and every time I touched it I flashed right back to that moment of terror. I felt squeamish enough about it that it deterred me from doing really thorough breast exams.¬†In hindsight, I probably should have just had it out. ¬†Ironically, once I finally got brave enough to go looking for it again, I couldn't find it. ¬†Even the nurse who did my clinical exam four days ago didn't say a word about it. ¬†I think that one just went away on its own! With this third one, I don't know what I'm going to do. ¬†I'd love to avoid another 2 inch scar, but I think keeping it is going to make me anxious. ¬†I'll see what the doctor says. If I were you, I think I'd have it out and be done with it if the alternative is going to be checks every 6 months. ¬†That sounds a lot more stressful than living with a scar, which I probably could have minimized if someone had told me about Vitamin E oil at the time. ¬†Oh well, live and learn, right? Good luck, and sleep well tonight! ¬†
Posts.Title: Scared to Death.. DeJaVuAgain Kelloggs

Posts.Content: PurpleCat wrote: I had a consult at the lymphedema clinic yesterday, more as a precaution and to stay ahead of things than because I was having problems not still related to surgery. The pain and flexibility in the left arm have improved quite a bit in the week since I was referred there, so between that and the techniques I learned and the sleeve I'm about to get, I feel pretty well talked down off the cliff, so to speak, regarding my fear of lymphedema. Well, this morning I woke up with pain in my RIGHT armpit. It feels a lot like the left side has: tightness when I stretch, a sense of tenderness but feels OK when I actually touch it, etc. One of the massage techniques she showed me was to massage that armpit, so maybe I was just too vigorous and it's complaining now, or maybe it's referred or sympathy pain from the other arm, or maybe it's the cancer coming back. Or maybe it's a swollen lymph node because I do feel like I"m catching a cold, but I'm afraid to go feeling around for it because feeling a lump would bring on PTSD. This post probably belongs in the "emotional health" forum, but I thought maybe someone here would know whether a first lymphedema massage can annoy the rest of the lymph system? Dx 10/2018, IDC, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 10/4/2018 Lumpectomy Surgery 10/18/2018 Lymph node removal: Sentinel Hormonal Therapy Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Radiation Therapy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Can't win for losing PurpleCat PurpleCat

Posts.Content: PurpleCat wrote: They did my mammogram and ultrasound this morning, and were able to get me in for a biopsy already this afternoon, so that's a little less waiting, which is good. ¬†They found 2 things close together: a large cyst, which they aspirated, and something they seem to think is probaby a fibroadenoma again. ¬†Of course, my mind is going in all directions. ¬†The nurse who did an exam this morning before the imaging said it felt to her like a fibro, so now I have no idea if the solid lump was actually moveable or if it was just the cyst we were able to move around. ¬†The cyst was also quite a big bigger than the fibro, so I'm feeling really confused. ¬†Also, to my eyes, some of the ultrasound images looked bumpier and less regular than the other fibro images I've had, so that's not reassuring. ¬†I was feeling pretty good after this morning's imaging, but now am really wound up again. ¬†The biopsy results may be in as early as tomorrow afternoon, so that's a mercy. ¬†I really thought I'd feel better after today's imaging, but right now I just feel scared to death.¬† Ugh, this waiting is sheer torture. ¬†¬† Dx 10/2018, IDC, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 10/4/2018 Lumpectomy Surgery 10/18/2018 Lymph node removal: Sentinel Hormonal Therapy Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Radiation Therapy Log in to post a reply
